title: Our Team
text:
Jesse Naidoo

Director
PhD, University of Chicago
Jesse’s research interests include the interaction of formal and informal finance, retirement savings, and how households use the financial system to navigate major life events like death and divorce.



 





Allan Davids

Senior Researcher
PhD, University of Cape Town
Allan’s research focusses on housing, which is often the largest asset and largest liability for households. He focusses on how housing and credit decisions can be a driver of wealth inequality.



 





Matthew Olckers

Senior Researcher
PhD, Paris School of Economics
Matthew’s research interests include retirement saving, financial advice, and informal borrowing. His past research includes projects on financial literacy, adoption of mobile money, and sports betting.

title: Centre for Household Finance
text:
We are a research group within the Department of Economics at Stellenbosch University. Our goal is to advance knowledge about consumer financial markets in developing countries: how they work, and which policies may make them work more efficiently and more equitably.
We use tools from applied microeconomics and causal inference to study how people make financial decisions and what influences their choices. We focus on South African survey and administrative data in a variety of domains, including retirement, insurance, and credit.

title: Centre for Household Finance
text:
News

March, 2025: We welcomed Dr Matthew Olckers as a senior researcher and founding member of our group. Matthew has worked on a range of household finance topics, including retirement saving and financial literacy.
February, 2025: Dr Allan Davids, a senior lectuer at the University of Cape Town, has joined our group as an affiliated researcher and founding member. Allan’s research focusses on housing and credit.
January, 2025: Dr Jesse Naidoo joined Stellenbosch University as the founding director of our research centre. Here is an interview with Jesse where he describes his vision for the Centre.

title: Centre for Household Finance
text:
We aim to document differences in offer probabilities and in offered interest rates for mortgage applicants of different characteristics, e.g. age, sex, marital status, and first-time buyer status.



Funeral insurance is a widely purchased product in South Africa, while life insurance is purchased by only a small minority of consumers. We aim to document the extent to which these two products are substitutable on both the supply and demand side of the market. On the supply side, for example, this may include regulatory barriers; on the demand side, this might include differences in mortality rates, wealth, or family structure (including, e.g. patterns of intergenerational coresidence).
